passage.text: Oxidative removal of bisphenol A by permanganate: Kinetics, pathways and influences of co-existing chemicals
Relevant resource
True|False
Abstract

► KMnO4 was very effective and selective for BPA degradation. ► BPA oxidation by KMnO4 was significantly enhanced with increasing temperature. ► A parabola-like shaped pH-rate profile for BPA oxidation by aqueous permanganate was found over the pH range of 4.0–11.0. ► The pathways of BPA oxidation by KMnO4 were proposed for the first time. Batch experiments were carried out to investigate the decomposition of bisphenol A (BPA) by permanganate. Permanganate (100 μM) was very effective for BPA degradation and over 99% BPA (5 μM) was eliminated in 15 min at pH 7.0. A parabola-like shaped pH-rate profile for BPA oxidation by aqueous permanganate was found over the pH range of 4.0–11.0. The rate constants of permanganate reaction with BPA were strongly dependent on temperature and the activation energy was determined to be 67.8 kJ mol−1. Eleven degradation intermediates were observed by LC–MS/MS and the pathways of BPA degradation by permanganate were proposed. The intermediates generated in the processes of BPA oxidation by permanganate, ferrate, ozone, chlorine or hydroxyl radical indicated that benzoic ring was the reaction site at the early stage of BPA oxidation by various oxidants. The presence of humic acid (HA), HCO3-, Fe2+ and Fe3+ at their environmentally relevant concentrations enhanced BPA removal following the order: HA > HCO3- > Fe2+> Fe3+. BPA degradation in tap water, river water, and synthetic water at pH 7.0 was faster than that in deionized water, indicating that permanganate was selective for BPA oxidation. These results suggested that permanganate oxidation is an effective method for the purification of waters containing phenolic EDCs.

Introduction

Endocrine disrupting chemicals (EDCs) can mimic the biological activity of natural hormones, occupy (but not active) the hormone receptors, or interfere the transport and metabolic processes of natural hormones . As one of the representative EDCs, bisphenol A (BPA), which is largely used in the plastic industry as a monomer for production of epoxy resins and polycarbonate, is a xenobiotic that can be released into the environment from bottles, packaging, landfill leachate, paper, and plastics plants . The wide usage in household and commercial products has resulted in a large amount of BPA released into the environment and its wide presence in river water with concentration at the level of ng L−1–μg L−1. The removal of BPA from the river water and other drinking water sources has become an important environmental problem. Several methods have been developed to remove BPA from water including activated carbon adsorption, electrochemical oxidation, ozonation, photocatalytic decomposition and biological procedures . BPA adsorption on activated carbon was preferred at acidic or mildly basic pH values while it decreased significantly with rising pH due to the repulsive electrostatic interactions between the negatively charged carbon surface and the bisphenolate anion . Although BPA was rapidly degraded during drinking water disinfection using free chlorine, chlorination may generate chlorinated disinfection byproducts . Ozonation was highly effective in treating emerging micropollutants such as EDCs containing electron-rich moieties. Phenolic moieties of BPA could be rapidly oxidized with second-order rate constants of 1.22 × 105, 1.71 × 105, and 2.59 × 105 M−1 s−1 for ozone dosages of 1.4, 2.2, and 5.1 mg L−1, respectively, at pH 7.0 . However, when bromide was present in water, ozonation suffered from the potential formation of carcinogenic bromated byproducts . Another promising technology for oxidative removal of BPA is the application of permanganate (Mn(VII); KMnO4) . Permanganate has been widely used in potable water treatment for enhancing coagulation and removing micropollutants and in remediation of contaminated groundwater . Previous studies noted that the presence of small fraction of humic acid (HA) could accelerate the oxidation of phenols and triclosan by permanganate. However, in other oxidative processes, such as ozonation, photocatalytic oxidation and Fenton reaction, the presence of HA inhibited the removal of organic pollutants . Therefore, permanganate may have a higher selectivity for BPA oxidation in natural water, which is generally rich of HA, compared with other oxidants. In addition, permanganate has several obvious advantages, such as relatively low cost, ease of handling, effectiveness over a wide pH range, and comparative stability . Although permanganate is a promising oxidant for BPA removal from aqueous solution, the degradation of BPA by permanganate was rarely investigated except Jiang et al. , who only reported the kinetics and the influence of pH on BPA degradation. The degradation pathway has not been referred in any previous research. Therefore, the objectives of this study were to (1) determine the kinetics of BPA removal by permanganate in aqueous solution as functions of reactant concentration, pH and temperature; (2) detect the intermediates of reaction and propose reasonable BPA degradation pathways; (3) examine the influence of co-existing chemicals on this process to show the selectivity of permanganate oxidation.
Experimental section
Reagents and chemicals

BPA, KMnO4 and the scavenger Na2S2O3 were of analytical grade (Supporting information, Text S1). A commercial HA purchased from Jiangxi Reagent Co., Ltd., China, was used as a surrogate of humic substance and purified by repeated pH adjustment, precipitation, and centrifugation to remove ash, humin, and fulvic acid, completely following the procedure described by Kilduff and Weber . The stock solutions of CaCl2, Mg(NO3)2, NaHCO3, Na2SO4, FeCl3, FeCl2, Na2SiO3 were prepared from the corresponding analytical reagent chemicals to determine the influence of co-solutes on BPA oxidation by permanganate. Experiments were also conducted to test the effects of background matrices on BPA oxidation by dosing BPA to river water, tap water and synthetic water (Text S1).
Batch experiments and analyses

All experiments on the kinetics of BPA oxidation by KMnO4 were conducted in brown glass bottles with stopples at pH 7.0 ± 0.1 and 20 ± 1 °C unless otherwise specified. The headspace of the glass bottles to aqueous phase ratio was 1:10 by volume. In a typical experiment, brown glass bottles containing 200 mL of BPA and 30 mM NaCl (as background electrolyte) were put in water bath for at least 30 min to ensure the temperature of the reactant was 20 °C. The experiments were initiated after addition of an aliquot of the permanganate stock solution into the reactor while stirring, and the reaction lasted 20 min. At fixed time intervals 10 mL of sample was rapidly transferred with a syringe to a small beaker containing 100 μL of Na2S2O3 (0.1 M) to terminate the reaction immediately, and filtrated with a membrane filter (pore size, 0.22 μm). The concentration of residual BPA was analyzed directly by HPLC. No buffer was used at pH 4.0–7.0 and borate buffer was used at pH 8.0–9.0. The pH values changed very little (<0.1) during the whole process and all pH values reported were initial pH. The residual trace amount of MnO2 after filtration and ionic strength (30 mM NaCl) had little effects on the BPA degradation (data not shown). It should be notified that the initial concentration of permanganate was controlled at 10 μM in order to keep consistent with the pilot application in the experiments to verify the influence of co-existing ions on BPA oxidation by permanganate. All experiments were run in duplicates or triplicates, and all points in the figures are the mean of the results and error bars represent standard deviation of the means. BPA concentration was quantified by HPLC on a Waters e2695 instrument with a Symmetry C18 column (2.1 mm × 150 mm, 3.5 μm) and UV–Visible detector (Waters 2489) set at 280 nm. The mobile phase, water/methanol (30/70, v/v), was run in an isocratic mode and the flow rate was 1 mL min−1. The intermediates were identified by LC–MS/MS (Text S2 and Table S1). BPA mineralization (DOC removal) was examined with a TOC-VCPH analyzer (Shimadzu).
Results and discussion
Reaction order and constants of permanganate with BPA

The reaction law of BPA with permanganate was investigated with a molar ratio of permanganate to BPA ⩾ 5:1 in a batch reactor. The loss of BPA followed pseudo-first-order kinetics within the time scales investigated, as illustrated in Fig. 1a. For a constant concentration of BPA (5 μM) at pH 7.0, the pseudo-first-order rate constant (kobs, s−1) increased linearly as increasing Mn(VII) concentration from 25 to 150 μM (Fig. 1b), demonstrating a first-order dependence of the reaction on Mn(VII). Thus, the oxidation kinetics of BPA by Mn(VII) could be described by a second-order rate law: -d[BPA]dt=kobs[BPA]=kapp[KMnO4][BPA] lnkobs=lnkapp+ln[KMnO4] where kapp (M−1 s−1) was the second-order reaction rate constant. kapp at pH 7.0 and 20 °C was determined to be 28.53 M−1 s−1, slightly smaller than the kapp (35.8 M−1 s−1) at 23 °C reported by Jiang et al. . To sum up, the reaction between BPA and permanganate was of second-order in total and first-order with respect to each reactant. The reaction rate of permanganate with BPA is of the same order as photo-catalytic degradation of BPA with kapp of 72 M−1 s−1 at pH 7.0 and 25 °C , while ferrate oxidation (BPA = 10 μM and ferrate = 100–300 μM, at pH 7.0 and 25 °C) is an order faster than permanganate oxidation . However, ferrate is difficult to handle, prepare and store for its instability in water. The rate of ozonation is about 103 times higher than that of permanganate oxidation , but the bromated byproducts generated from ozonation should be paid attention and the hydroxyl radicals have no selectivity for target contaminants. In a short, even though the rate of permanganate oxidation showed fewer significant advantages over the other oxidative reactions, the lower reactivity can be counter-balanced by its relatively longer lifetime and high selectivity for the phenolic organics in real waters, which will further discussed in this study.
Effect of temperature on BPA degradation

BPA oxidation by permanganate was strongly dependent on temperature since the kapp of BPA destruction by permanganate increased significantly from 16.32 to 1.03 × 102 M−1 s−1 within creasing temperatures from 10 °C to 30 °C, as shown in Fig. 2 and Table S2. lnkapp=lnA-EaRT According to the Arrhenius equation (Eq. (3)), plotting ln(kapp) vs. 1/T would yield a linear curve, as shown in Fig. 2, and the activation energy (Ea) was determined to be 67.8 kJ mol−1. This Ea value was very close to that of antibiotics (lincomycin, 68.4 kJ mol−1) oxidation by permanganate .
Effect of pH on BPA degradation

Fig. 3 demonstrates that the rate of BPA oxidation by permanganate is heavily dependent on pH. There was a slight increase in kapp as pH decreased from 5.0 to 4.0, which should be associated with acid catalysis under increased [H+] condition . kapp experienced two-orders of magnitude increase as pH increased from 5.0 to 9.0, which was very similar to the results reported by Jiang et al. . The removal rates of antibiotics, dyes and textiles by permanganate in aqueous solution also increased with increasing pH from 5.0 to 9.0 . However, the reaction of permanganate with BPA slowed down at pH over 10.0. A comparison of the pH-dependent second-order rate constants of BPA oxidation by permanganate, chlorine and ozone was made in Fig. 3. At near neutral pH, permanganate exhibited comparable reactivity with chlorine but much lower reactivity than ozone. The interesting phenomenon that kapp reached their maximum at BPA’s first pKa (9.2) in all the three oxidative processes and then decreased, similar to the behavior of chlorophenols oxidation by permanganate . But the mechanism about this phenomenon was still unclear and further studies are necessary. The traditional explanation that the increase of reaction rate with increasing pH was caused by the stronger electron-donating strength of the hydroxyl groups after their deprotonation, seemed questionable based on our result. For example, the rate of BPA oxidation by permanganate slowed down as pH increased from 10.0 to 11.0 although the fraction of BPA2− increased, which may be due to the unfavorable repulsion between permanganate anions and BPA2− anions.
Pathways of BPA by permanganate oxidation

Although many studies have made efforts to explore the BPA oxidation pathways in various processes , the mechanisms of BPA degradation by permanganate were kept unknown. Eleven reaction intermediates were detected besides BPA by LC–MS/MS. Eight of the eleven intermediates had been observed in other oxidation processes while the other three, with m/z 248, 246 and 196 were reported for the first time, as summarized in Table S3 and Fig. S1. All the intermediates eluted earlier than BPA, indicating that they were more polar than their parent compound . To elucidate the reaction pathways of BPA with permanganate, the intermediates detected in various oxidation processes were also compiled in Table S3. Relying on the intermediates specified in this study, Adamezyk and Paneth’s theoretical evaluation and the reaction pathways of BPA with other oxidants, the possible pathways of BPA with permanganate were proposed and illustrated in Fig. 4. In the early stage of the reaction, permanganate oxidized phenolic compounds through [3 + 2] addition across the O–Mn–O, followed by a hydride abstraction (rate-limiting step) from the substrate to permanganate oxo group . It could be speculated that hydrogen abstraction contributed to the formation of mono-hydroxylated BPA (m/z 244), which was further degraded to m/z 242, followed by the ring cleavage. The 4-isopropenylphenol (m/z 134) was the smallest molecular with benzoic ring detected in this study. Its concentration reached the maximum in less than 30 min, while ∼99% of BPA was degraded in the first 15 min and only 50% mineralization achieved (as DOC) in 3 h (Fig. S2). It implied that the precursors of 4-isopropenylphenol were susceptible to oxidization while its degradation products were resistant to permanganate oxidation. This phenomenon was similar to BPA mineralization by ozone, during which additional 4 h of ozonation only achieved about 16% additional DOC removal . According to the previous studies, 4-isopropenylphenol was further decomposed slowly to other simple intermediates, e.g., hydroquinone, benzoquinone and simple organic acids . But neither of hydroquinone and benzoquinone was detected in our research, probably due to their low concentrations or the improper analysis conditions. Maleic acid and tartaric acid were identified. Although the formation and transformation of these products offered us a reasonable and believable mechanism of BPA degradation, it could not be excluded that some other intermediates were generated in the process of BPA oxidation by permanganate but could not be detected. The initial degradation byproducts (m/z 244, 242, 276 and 152) of BPA verified in permanganate, ferrate, manganese dioxide, ozone and hydroxyl oxidation processes showed no change on the alkyl group, as listed in Table S3, indicating that the benzoic ring was the reaction site at early stage of BPA oxidation by various oxidants. The mono-hydroxylated BPA was the first product derived from BPA by adding the second –OH group on the ring in permanganate oxidation (Fig. 4). Many studies have reported that the phenolic moiety is the essential functional group responsible for the strong estrogenicity, while the quinone-like and aromatic ring-opening oxidation products hold much weaker estrogenic potency . Fang et al. also pointed out that the –OH substituent on the ring exhibited binding activity toward the receptors via H-bond interaction . Therefore, it was speculated that the addition of second –OH substituent of mono-hydroxylated BPA would increase the binding affinity to receptors and improve the estrogenic potency. The intermediates of m/z 244, 242, 276, 152 and 134, appeared in both permanganate oxidation and ozonation of BPA, indicating the similar oxidative pathways in these two processes. Alum et al. pointed out the level of elicited BPA estrogenicity increased during the first half hour and then decreased during ozonation . Therefore, the estrogenic change of BPA in permanganate oxidation might experience an increase before a decrease. Thus, it was necessary to keep enough contact time for BPA degradation by permanganate to eliminate the estrogenicity. There was a serious polymerization in the manganese dioxide oxidation and six of the ten byproducts were derived from the re-combination of the produced fragments , which was not observed in this study probably due to the low concentration of MnO2 generated. The structures of simple organic acids (the last byproducts before total mineralization) are very different for different oxidation processes, mainly due to the oxidizing ability of different oxidants. There were numbers of studies investigating the degradation products of BPA generated in various advanced oxidation processes, which led to abundant information about the byproducts produced via OH. No polymerization was found in hydroxyl oxidation, except m/z 454. The intermediates in chlorination of BPA were all the halogenated BPA and were not discussed here.
Effect of co-existing materials on BPA degradation efficiency

Most studies on permanganate oxidation were carried out in distilled water and the effects of the background matrixes in the natural water were rarely taken into account . However, the presence of inorganic and organic solutes may affect permanganate oxidation and thus influence the removal rates of target contaminants. Herein, the effects of four cations (Ca2+, Mg2+, Fe3+ and Fe2+), three anions (HCO3-, SO42- and SiO32-), and HA were studied at their own environmentally relevant concentrations at pH 7.0, as presented in Fig. 5 and Fig. S3. The presence of Ca2+ of 0–1.5 mM, Mg2+ of 0–1.6 mM, SO42- of 0–0.1 mM and SiO32- of 0–2.0 mM had negligible influences on BPA removal. Increasing Fe3+ from 0 to 20 μM enhanced the BPA removal rate from 34.1% to 49.3%. However, further increasing in its concentration resulted in a drop in the removal of BPA. Fe2+ did not inhibit BPA removal by permanganate over the concentration range of 5–60 μM. The maximum BPA removal rate (45.5%) was achieved in the presence of 20 μM Fe2+. Bicarbonate improved BPA removal almost linearly from 34.1% to 49.9% with increasing its concentration from 0 to 10 mM. The stimulative capacity of these ions at their own environmentally relevant concentrations generally followed the order: HCO3->Fe2+>Fe3+>Ca2+≈Mg2+≈SO42-≈SiO32-·HCO3- exhibited the strongest promotion on BPA degradation by permanganate compared to other ions studied. The recent study has proved the HCO3- can participant the hydroxyl oxidation acting as CO3·- or HCO3·, but we certified there was no intervention of free radicals in our system according to Kini et al. . Therefore, the mechanism of HCO3- was still ambiguous and needed further investigation. It has been certified that some strongly reduced species, e.g., As3+ and Mn2+, can enhance the removal of BPA by permanganate . Thus, Fe2+ may play a dual role, the reduced species and the same role as Fe3+, in permanganate oxidation process. Although the role of Fe3+ in permanganate oxidation has not been confirmed, Fe3+ might play a similar role to Ru3+, which was frequently used as catalyst in aqueous reactions including permanganate oxidation , for their similar electronic structures. The influence of HA on BPA degradation by permanganate was illustrated in Fig. 5c. BPA removal was improved from 34.1% to 73.8% by increasing HA concentration from 0 to 7.5 mg C L−1 as DOC. As reported by Nanny and Maza and Smejkalov et al. , the noncovalent interactions of HA with phenols were related to the formation of π–π interactions between the monoaromatic ring of substrates and HA aromatic components. The π–π interaction with HA could enhance the density of the electron cloud of phenol, which could result in the enhancement of phenol oxidation by permanganate. However, further increasing HA concentration from 7.5 to 10.0 mg C L−1 resulted in a decline in BPA removal from 73.8% to 57.9%. This may be attributable to the fact that HA of high concentration exerted a significant demand for permanganate and reduced the available oxidant for BPA destruction . To sum up, comparing our results to other techniques such as ozonation and advanced oxidation processes, the reaction rate of permanganate oxidation was lower. But none of the co-existing ions examined in our study displayed negative influence while Fe2+, Fe3+, HCO3- and HA could enhance permanganate oxidation. This may indicate that permanganate oxidation bored high selectivity for BPA in real water with various background matrixes. Therefore, BPA spiked in tap water, river water, and synthetic water was removed by permanganate at pH 7.0, as shown in Fig. 5d. Apparently, compared to the oxidation kinetics obtained in deionized water, BPA oxidation was accelerated in all of these three water matrices, consistent with the influence of co-existing ions on permanganate oxidation process. The latest research also showed that permanganate oxidation was more effective than chlorination and ozonation in treatment of surface water and wastewater effluent at pH 8.0 when the oxidant doses were relatively low . However, many other processes suffered from lower BPA removal rates in real water than in deionized water background. Lee et al. reported that the water matrix of natural water or wastewater may compete with BPA for ferrate, resulting in a lower removal rate of BPA in real water than in deionized water . Frontistis et al. compared the removal rate of BPA by photo-electro-catalysis in ultrapure water and that in a secondary treated effluent under same conditions and found that the removal rate of BPA in secondary treated effluent was 50% lower than that in ultrapure water . The presence of organic matter, which can consume photo-generated reactive species, and inorganics like bicarbonates, which act as radical scavengers, may be responsible for decreased conversions in treated effluent. The presence of HA also decreased BPA removal in zero-valent aluminum–acid system and resulted in a diminution of the Mn-catalytic ozonation of atrazine . Consequently, permanganate oxidation is a promising process for eliminating BPA from real water compared to other processes.
Conclusions

This study demonstrated that permanganate was a good alternative for the treatment of aqueous phenolic EDCs. BPA removal was highly pH and temperature dependent. A parabola-like shaped pH-rate profile for BPA oxidation by permanganate was found in the pH range of 4.0–11.0. The proposed reaction pathways of BPA degradation by permanganate were very similar to those of BPA destruction by ozonation. Benzoic ring was the reaction site at the early stage of BPA oxidation by permanganate, ferrate, ozone, chlorine and hydroxyl radical. The co-existing solutes in the natural water had no negative effects on the BPA degradation and the presence of HCO3-, Fe2+, Fe3+ and HA could enhance the BPA removal to different degrees. Although BPA can be effectively removed by many advanced oxidation processes in pure water, permanganate is stable, inexpensive, and more importantly, permanganate oxidation showed highly selectivity for BPA in real water. Therefore, permanganate oxidation is a promising process for BPA removal from natural water with various background solutes.
